page.title: 14BRIGHSTONE COASTGUARDS.
page.content: The coastguard station is just out of our area but they are responsible for a long stretch of coast including our block. In the nineteenth century the coastguard service was primarily concerned with the control of smuggling but in 1854 they were given safety and rescue equipment. In the next 53 years 9000 lives were saved and they built up a reputation for never failing to offer help. Today 800 vessels a day go through the Channel. Watch is kept mainly by radar from the main stations at Falmouth and Dover. Brighstone is an auxilliary station but it still has 20 men who have a practice drill twice a month. One of the most useful items of equipment is a pistol which can fire a rope up to a mile distant to haul someone in.
